perturbation.original_text:
Accounting statements and, if applicable, royalty payments
         for products sold will be rendered by each party quarterly within sixty
         (60) days after the expiration of each calendar quarter.
perturbation.changed_text:
Accounting statements and, if applicable, royalty payments
         for products sold will be rendered by each party quarterly within ninety
         (90) days after the expiration of each calendar quarter.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces a contradiction with the later part of this section.  While the first sentence now states '90 days', the subsequent text regarding the audit period remains tied to the original '60 day' accounting statement delivery.  This creates uncertainty: does a party have only 2 years from 60 days post-quarter to audit, or 2 years from 90 days post-quarter?

perturbation.original_text:
Either party, at its sole expense, upon at least
         thirty (30) days written notice (and not more than once in respect of
         any accounting period) will have the right to inspect the other party's
         books regarding the obligations hereunder for a period of two (2) years
         from the date on which any statement is rendered. Such auditing party
         must make specific written objection within such two (2) year period.
         Thereafter, it will be deemed to have consented to any such statements
         or accountings which will then be considered an account stated as
         between the parties, not subject to any objection for any reason
         whatsoever. Provided the objecting party has made timely written
         objection, as aforesaid, such party may file an action regarding same
         within two (2) years and six (6) months after the applicable statement
         is rendered, after which time any such action will be deemed barred.
perturbation.changed_text:
Either party, at its sole expense, upon at least
         thirty (30) days written notice (and not more than once in respect of
         any accounting period) will have the right to inspect the other party's
         books regarding the obligations hereunder for a period of one (1) year
         from the date on which any statement is rendered. Such auditing party
         must make specific written objection within such two (2) year period.
         Thereafter, it will be deemed to have consented to any such statements
         or accountings which will then be considered an account stated as
         between the parties, not subject to any objection for any reason
         whatsoever. Provided the objecting party has made timely written
         objection, as aforesaid, such party may file an action regarding same
         within two (2) years and six (6) months after the applicable statement
         is rendered, after which time any such action will be deemed barred.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a direct contradiction regarding the audit period. It first says the audit period is *one (1) year* from the statement date, but then says the auditing party *must make specific written objection within such two (2) year period* and can file an action within *two (2) years and six (6) months after the applicable statement is rendered.* It's unclear whether the audit is restricted to 1 year or whether that is extended to a full 2 years and 6 months. This ambiguity undermines enforceability.

perturbation.original_text:
Thereafter, the
         parties must mutually agree in writing to extend the term for
         additional periods of time.
perturbation.changed_text: Thereafter, the term shall automatically renew for successive one-year periods, unless either party provides written notice of termination at least ninety (90) days prior to the expiration of the initial term or any renewal term. Upon agreement by both parties, the term can be extended for a period other than a year, or terminated prior to the automatic renewal.
perturbation.explanation: This change directly contradicts the original text. The original requires mutual written agreement to extend the term. The new text implements an automatic renewal unless a party objects, but also allows for different renewal periods or premature termination if both parties agree.  This creates confusion about the actual term and the process for ending the agreement.
